Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Advancing Organoelement Synthesis through alpha Elimination and Hydrophosphination Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Rory Waterman. Professor Waterman is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Vermont. The objective of this proposal is to discover and understand catalytic reactions that form phosphorus-carbon and silicon-carbon bonds. Central to meeting that objective is utilizing abundant metals as catalysts to afford divergent chemical reactivity of phosphorus-hydrogen and silicon-hydrogen bonds with a variety of reagents. Two specific reactions will be explored: alpha elimination and hydrophosphination. Alpha elimination is a rare and relatively new reaction with the potential to facilitate the synthesis of complex molecular structures. These structures have applications in materials science, catalysis, and biomedicine. Hydrophosphination is a well-established transformation, but questions and limitations remain. Overcoming these challenges makes this reaction available for broader use in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, for example. Improved understanding in both reactions would advance the multi-billion dollar field of catalysis. Professor Waterman has been able to successfully recruit students underrepresented in the sciences, provide research experiences for high school students, and engage in educational outreach with K-12 students, practices to be continued in this project.

The proposal explores two unique kinds of catalysis to understand and improve the catalytic preparation of E- carbon (C) (E = phosphorus or silicon) bonds, recognizing that abundant and inexpensive metals can be enlisted to produce divergent reactivity upon E-hydrogen (H) bond activation in the presence of unsaturated substrates. Through a series of testable hypotheses, a validated set of design features for alpha elimination catalysis is sought. This reaction may result in the efficient synthesis of phosphorus- and silicon-containing molecules via catalytic E-C bond formation is a key driver. Prior discoveries in this group demonstrate that such new reactivity is possible, and efforts in this area seek to improve understanding of M-E bonding and reaction chemistry. Efforts to discover new and highly efficient syntheses of chiral-at-phosphorus ligands though hydrophosphination provide a platform to address those fundamental issues and broaden the understanding and utility of this key P-C bond forming reaction. Beyond the benefit of these reactions to fields such as materials science, energy, and biomedicine, the outreach program includes direct research experiences for high school students in support of project goals.

Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF support through CHE-1565658 led to three major outcomes: First, significant gains in our understanding of catalytic reactions that form bonds to silicon and phosphorus were realized. Catalytic reactions improve our efficiency in building molecules and materials with these elements that are critical to life, energy applications, and consumer goods. We disseminated this understanding including new catalysts and how these catalysts work. In particular, we identified the first example of a-silylene elimination, a reaction that compliments reported preparation of organosilanes and silicon-based polymers. We reported the first example of a-phosphinidene elimination that directly gave organophosphine products that are relevant for catalysis and materials science. We made tremendous strides in the study of hydrophosphination catalysis or the addition of a P-H bond across a substrate. These reactions are ?green,? generating no additional waste. We identified an active iron catalyst that also ready undergoes so-called double hydrophosphination to afford 1,2-diphopshinoethanes, which are privileged molecules in support of late-metal catalysis such a hydrogenation or cross coupling. Beside using a highly abundant metal, these reactions can be initiated with visible light, leading to additional efficiency. We continued to make substantial gains with zirconium catalysts, discovering that catalytic hydrophosphination was driven by light, which was investigated. Leveraging that understanding, we increased the efficiency and speed of those reactions, developed more potential substrates, and made unique products. These results highlights that our zirconium catalysts are still the most versatile for hydrophosphination and the discovery of photocatalysis lofts these back into the most active known for any substrate. These advances contributed to the intellectual merit of the project. Catalysis is, itself, a multibillion-dollar industry, and many of the reactions and products noted support major industries including pharmaceuticals, consumer goods, and materials. Thus, this fundamental work and understanding will be a driver for significant future economic gain, which is one of the broader impacts of the work (more below).       

Second, the research provided an excellent venue to train undergraduate and graduate students for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) careers. As the pace of technological advance remains high, training for single skills is a disservice to our workforce. Thus, complex and long-term projects in basic research teach core problem-solving skills coupled with current high-tech instrumentation that affords intellectually agile individuals. Participants honed key oral and verbal communication skills through participation in written dissemination of the results and formal presentations.     

Third, the research was a venue to entice younger students to science. Several local high school students engaged in research projects in support of objectives in this award. The programs that we participate in for the recruiting of students place emphases on increasing participation in science, and we have hosted women and students of color in these projects. All participating high school students who have graduated matriculated at a four-year undergraduate institution (i.e., they went to college) and at least started their college careers with a declared STEM major. Many undergraduate and graduate student participants on this award have a strong personal interest in STEM/science outreach. The set of participating individuals (including the PI) have logged dozens of hours in K-6 science outreach activities in various venues.      

As this all occurred, we have been involved in the development and dissemination of Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs). A CURE was developed at the University of Vermont that indirectly supported the goals of this project but provided more than two dozen students unique research experiences that resulted in measurable gains in their understanding of STEM concepts as well as advance intellectual goals of research.       


Last Modified: 06/16/2019
Modified by: Rory Waterman

Catalytic reactions improve our efficiency in building molecules and materials with these elements that are critical to life, energy applications, and consumer goods. We identified an active iron catalyst that also ready undergoes so-called double hydrophosphination to afford 1,2-diphopshinoethanes, which are privileged molecules in support of late-metal catalysis such a hydrogenation or cross coupling.
